I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The ensuing National Roads Development Project (Kalimantan) will improve national and 
regional connectivity by (i) rehabilitating and upgrading about 280 kilometers (km) of road sections 
in North Kalimantan Province and East Kalimantan Province, (ii) strengthen the capacity of the 
Directorate General of Highways (DGH) of the Ministry of Public Works and Housing (MPWH) for 
designing roads with road safety, biodiversity, and climate change considerations; and (iii) 
enhance road safety along the project road sections. The ensuing project will support Indonesia’s 
post coronavirus disease (COVID-19) economic recovery by helping to create jobs through 
increase road transport efficiency and support integrated and sustainable economic growth. The 
total cost of the project is estimated at $380.0 million. ADB will provide financing in an amount 
equivalent to $300.0 million from its ordinary capital resources. The government will finance $80.0 
million including taxes and duties. The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) subproject 
under Sustainable Infrastructure Assistance Program Phase II (SIAP2) is included in the country 
operations business plan for Indonesia, 2020–2022 (COBP).  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
2.  The TA subproject will support the preparation of a loan focused on quality road project 
design and transport sector development in Kalimantan, Republic of Indonesia. The TA is a 
subproject under the transaction TA cluster (C-TA 0040-INO) SIAP2, financed by the Government 
of Australia through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and administered by Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).1 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
3.  SIAP2 was approved on 29 November 2018 and is due to close on 30 June 2024. SIAP2 
provides: (i) project preparation support to specific ensuing infrastructure projects listed in ADB’s 
current and future COBPs for Indonesia; (ii) implementation and capacity-building support to 
specific ongoing ADB-funded infrastructure projects; and (iii) knowledge and policy advisory 
support in the areas of infrastructure planning and financing, together with program management 
support for effective SIAP2 implementation.2 As of 6 April 2020, total approvals are $15.40 million 
(51% of total funds), of which $0.22 million has been disbursed, and total available balance is 
$14.60 million.3 
 
B.  Subproject Scope 
4.  The  TA  subproject  will  conduct  a  prioritization  exercise  and  assist  ADB  and  the 
government to identify sections of the roads suitable for ADB financing in the North and East 
Kalimantan provinces. The TA will include activities to prepare the feasibility study and conduct 
due diligence for ADB processing of the ensuing project. The feasibility study produced will then 
be used to prepare the detailed design for the ensuing project, which will be funded under an

5.  The due diligence will include, but not be limited to: procurement capacity assessment, 
economic  and  financial  assessment,  financial  management  assessment,  environmental 
assessment, land acquisition and resettlement, gender, and social development. The TA will also 
support initial project start-up implementation, such as bidding, land acquisition, and resettlement 
of project affected persons, as required.

C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
7.  Output 1: Feasibility study for ensuing project prepared. This output will cover an 
engineering study, which will include geological, topographical, hydrological surveys, preliminary 
pavement design, detailed cost estimates, and an implementation plan. The economic study will 
include traffic surveys and an assessment of the economic feasibility of the project. The financial 
analysis will include a financial management assessment of the executing and/or implementing 
agency and a financial analysis of the project.  
 
8.  Output  2:  Safeguards  analysis  and  documentation  prepared.  The  social  and 
environmental studies will include the environmental assessment, poverty and social assessment, 
gender  analysis,  gender  action  plan,  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan,  stakeholder 
communication strategy, and consultation and community engagement plans. The proposed 
project will be designed taking into consideration the following: climate change and disaster 
resilience, sensitive social and environmental safeguards, gender mainstreaming, the need for 
paying attention to the ethnic minorities issues, obtaining broad community support of impacted 
ethnic minority communities and documentation of the same.  The project team will also explore 
environmentally sensitive interventions to include as potential project components. 
 
9.  Output  3:  Institutional  capacity  strengthened.  An  overview  of  the  road  sector 
performance in Kalimantan, in comparison with other regions in Indonesia as well as neighboring 
countries, will be prepared. The overview will cover a quantitative analysis of the impact of roads 
in Kalimantan, the strategic directions of executing/implementing agencies, through the analysis 
of key sector indicators of the road transport network (e.g. kilometers by category, existing 
conditions, current and projected traffic volumes, recent trends in the budget allocations and 
expenditures both for recurrent and capital costs). Recommendations on the road sector capacity 
strengthening activities under the ensuing project will be proposed, such as improvement of the

provincial road asset maintenance and management system within DGH. The TA will also include 
capacity strengthening activities that prepare the executing/implementing agencies to implement 
an ADB-financed project, in particular in procurement, financial management, and safeguards 
areas. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
10.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $1,031,000 of which $1,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Government of Australia through the Department of Foreign Affairs and 
Trade, and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
staff time and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
shown in Appendix 1. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
11.  ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants, and procure goods. ADB will hire 
a firm and an individual consultant  to provide the consultancy services to ensure integrated 
project delivery. The TA subproject does not include procurement of goods other than office 
equipment and workshop venues. The TA subproject will be implemented over 21 months and is 
expected to commence no later than May 2020.
